text: Hi guys and welcome back to part 7a of the Blackboard Learning Series. Now what we spoke about... throughout predominantly part 7a was, we started off with two types of auction rotations you can expect to find. And we said the first and most common is where we have a lot of two-time framing going on. So what do we mean by that? Well, very simply, it's merely where we get a lot of overlap between auction rotations. Now, if this is our first auction rotation and the next auction rotation, then the third auction rotation, and then maybe continue a little bit higher and then over the course of the day maybe head a little bit lower and effectively all we're getting there is a lot of two way type auction rotations. The more directional aggressive type is where we have a one time framing auction process and that merely is where we have a series of higher lows and higher highs or equally a series of lower highs and lower lows. The key identifier and what's important to understand is that when a market is either one time framing up or one time framing down, there is a sense of control from either the buyers and the sellers. We want to identify that control quite early so that we don't stand up against it but We then spoke very briefly about within these various auction rotations or individual TPO auctions we spoke about volatility contraction and expansion. Contraction is nothing more than when we have very narrow TPO print. So very, very relatively small but we move from very wide to suddenly very small. Equally, volatility expansion is merely the opposite where we move from having relatively and then contracting again. So again, we want to be able to differentiate between contracting, volatility contraction within the auction rotations as well as expansion. And the reason is that we want to identify what created that, what was the cause of that sudden shift in volatility, and then equally, why did we suddenly quieten down? Was it a case of we found responsive buying, was it a unwind what caused that volatility both contraction and expansion. The key thing to understand about the volume point of control, it is the price within a volume profile that transacts the highest amount of volume over a period of a day. a series, are there a series or a number of different prices that could have been the VPOC? What do we mean by that? For instance, if we have a whole bunch of prices and that is the VPOC relative to the average prices, or are there a few prices that potentially could have been the VPOC? These protruding ones tend to act as a sort of elastic band when the market moves away. fill out, whereas these types of VPOCs, they're not as prominent and sometimes they may hold initially or they may redirect. The important thing to understand with regards to the VPOC is that you can develop various strategies around the highest traded price of the day. Because we get a VPOC every single day, you can develop very, very specific strategies and execute those strategies in a highly successful manner.
